title: Ray Haggerty
text:
Raymond Louis Haggerty (April 6, 1923 – April 23, 2011) was a politician in <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, Canada. He was a <a href="Ontario%20Liberal%20Party">Liberal</a> member of the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Ontario">Legislative Assembly of Ontario</a> from 1967 to 1990 who represented the ridings of Welland South, Erie and Niagara South. He was also involved in municipal politics in the <a href="Welland">Welland</a> area from 1956 to 1967.
Background.
Haggerty was born in <a href="Port%20Colborne">Port Colborne</a>, <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a> and he was educated at <a href="Port%20Colborne">Port Colborne</a> High School. He worked as a machinist before entering politics. He and his wife Marie raised three children. He served as president of the Niagara South Plowman's Association.
Politics.
He served as a councillor in <a href="Bertie%20Township%2C%20Ontario">Bertie Township</a> in 1956-57, and was its deputy <a href="Reeve%20%28Canada%29">reeve</a> from 1960 to 1967. He was also a councillor in <a href="Welland">Welland</a> from 1960 to 1967.
He was elected to the Ontario legislature in the <a href="1967%20Ontario%20general%20election">1967 provincial election</a>, defeating <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Ontario">Progressive Conservative</a> candidate Gordon Taylor by 107 votes in the new riding of <a href="Welland%20South">Welland South</a>. In the <a href="1971%20Ontario%20general%20election">1971 election</a>, he was re-elected by 438 votes. Haggerty was returned by much greater majorities in the elections of <a href="1975%20Ontario%20general%20election">1975</a>, <a href="1977%20Ontario%20general%20election">1977</a>, <a href="1981%20Ontario%20general%20election">1981</a>, <a href="1985%20Ontario%20general%20election">1985</a> and <a href="1987%20Ontario%20general%20election">1987</a>. He did not seek re-election in 1990.
During his 23 year tenure, he served as a backbench supporter to Liberal leaders <a href="Robert%20Nixon%20%28politician%29">Bob Nixon</a>, <a href="Stuart%20Lyon%20Smith">Stuart Smith</a> and <a href="David%20Peterson">David Peterson</a>. When the Liberals took office in 1985 he served as a parliamentary assistant to several ministries including Government Services and Consumer and Commercial Relations.
